_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY A¿ OCEAN SPRAY CRANBERRIES, INC.

Ocean Spray Cranberries, Incorporated (Ocean Spray) in Kenosha, Wisconsin processes cranberries into juice and sauce products.  The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperature of all the products within the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is an effective refrigerant that has been used for many years by most food processing facilities.  Ammonia is normally a gas at ambient temperatures but is handled as a gas liquefied under pressure.  Each refrigeration system consists of a high-pressure receiver, evaporators, compressors, piping, and valves.  There are two ammonia systems within the facility.  One system (Main System) was estimated to hold approximately 11,200 pounds of ammonia, while the other system (Flex/Aseptic System) was estimated to hold approximately 9,300 pounds.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies: 
 Ocean Spray Cranberries, Inc. is committed to promoting safety for the plant, its employees and surrounding area.  The facility is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  The purpose of these programs is to ensure that the refrigeration system is operated safely in order to prevent releases of ammonia from the system.  In addition, these programs serve to develop procedures to minimize releases in the event that they do occur and to outline appropriate emergency response steps to take in the event of a release.  
                                                                                                                                      
The calculated inventory of the Main system indicates it is charged with over 10,000-pounds of ammonia. The calculated inventory of the Flex/Aseptic system indicates under 10,000-pounds of an ammonia charge.  The RMP and PSM rules require facilities to addre

ss only those processes that contain over the 10,000 pound threshold of ammonia unless a release of one process could result in a release from the other, or an external event to the processes (such as a fire or explosion) could have the potential to release ammonia from multiple containers.

Under most circumstances, a release from the Main system would not cause a release of the Flex/Aseptic system unless an external fire spreads from one vessel to the other.  Although there is a low likelihood that there would be a catastrophic fire that would engulf both processes, Ocean Spray has elected to include both systems in the RMP and PSM programs to ensure the safety of employees and surrounding areas. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps: 
As a part of its PSM Program, Ocean Spray has established numerous programs that serve to prevent accidental releases of ammonia.  The programs include:

A·Process Safety Information
A·Process Hazard Analysis
A·Operating Procedures
A·Training
A·Mechanical Integrity
A·Management of Change
A·Pre-startup Review
A·Compliance Audits
A·Incident Investigations
A·Employee Participation
A·Hot Work Permits
A·Contractor Safety

In addition, Ocean Spray has a sophisticated system of ammonia sensors.  These sensors are capable of detecting releases of ammonia at low levels, and are connected to a computer which signals the location of a release so trained plant personnel can take immediate response actions.

Emergency Response Information: 
As a part of the PSM Program, the facility maintains an Emergency Action and Response Plan that was prepared in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency incident, and to increase the reliability of action taken during an incident.  As a part of this emergency planning effort, employees receive emergency response training and are trained to provide minimal response and utilize the local Fire Department and HazMat team to respond to a large

ammonia leak.

In the event of an emergency involving the ammonia system, it is the policy of the facility to request assistance as necessary by calling 911 to notify the Kenosha Police Department, and the Kenosha Fire Department.  The Kenosha County Local Emergency Response Committee has included the Ocean Spray facility in its local emergency response planning.

Ocean Spray also partners with the local LEPC and Wisconsin Emergency Management to conduct ammonia release scenario table top exercises in addition to functional ammonia release exercises withe local EMS entities such as police, fire, hazmat, public works, hospitals and Red Cross.

Five-Year Accident History: 
In the past five years there have been no reportable ammonia releases, that resulted in off-site injuries, death, environmental damage, or external evacuations.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety:
Ocean Spray is in the planning stages with the Kenosha LEPC and Wisconsin Emergency Management to conduct a functional exercise in August 2019 involving a catastrophic ammonia release scenario.

The facility will continue to operate and maintain the system in accordance with appropriate safety standards and will continue to implement its OSHA PSM Program in conjunction with the Risk Management Program.
